summary.long: 1 Kings is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: King David had grown old, and although he was covered with blankets, he couldn’t get warm.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His officials told him, “Your Majesty, let us search for a young woman who has never been married. She can stay with you and be your servant. She can lie in your arms and keep you warm.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they searched throughout Israel for a beautiful, young woman. They found Abishag from Shunem and brought her to the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The woman was very beautiful. She became the king’s servant and took care of him, but the king did not make love to her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Adonijah, son of Haggith, was very handsome. His mother gave birth to him after she had Absalom. Adonijah was boasting that he was king. So he got a chariot and horses and 50 men to run ahead of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His father had never confronted him by asking why he was doing this.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Adonijah had discussed his actions with Joab (son of Zeruiah) and with the priest Abiathar, so they supported him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the priest Zadok, Benaiah (son of Jehoiada), the prophet Nathan, Shimei, Rei, and David’s thirty fighting men did not join Adonijah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Adonijah sacrificed sheep, cattle, and fattened calves at Zoheleth Rock near En Rogel. He had invited all his brothers, the king’s other sons, all the men of Judah, and the king’s officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he didn’t invite the prophet Nathan, Benaiah, the fighting men, or his brother Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Nathan asked Solomon’s mother Bathsheba, “Haven’t you heard that Adonijah, Haggith’s son, has become king, and our master David doesn’t even know about it?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bathsheba, let me give you some advice about how to save your life and your son’s life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Go to King David and ask him, ‘Your Majesty, didn’t you swear to me that my son Solomon will be king after you, and that he will sit on your throne? Why is Adonijah acting as king?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And while you’re still there talking to the king, I’ll come in and confirm what you have said.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bathsheba went to the king in his private room. The king was very old, and Abishag from Shunem was taking care of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bathsheba knelt and bowed down in front of the king. “What do you want?” the king asked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Sir,” she answered, “You took an oath to the Lord your God. You said that my son Solomon will be king after you, and that he will sit on your throne.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now, you see, Adonijah has become king, and you don’t even know anything about it, Your Majesty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He has sacrificed many fattened calves, bulls, and sheep. He has invited all the king’s sons, Abiathar the priest, and Joab the commander of the army to his feast. But he hasn’t invited your servant Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All Israel is looking to you, Your Majesty, to tell them who should succeed you on your throne.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Otherwise, my son Solomon and I will be treated like criminals when you lie down in death with your ancestors.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While she was still talking to the king, the prophet Nathan arrived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The servants told the king, “The prophet Nathan is here.” When he came to the king, he bowed down in front of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nathan said, “Your Majesty, you must have said that Adonijah will be king after you and that he will sit on your throne,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because today he went and sacrificed many bulls, fattened calves, and sheep. He invited all the king’s sons, the army’s commanders, and the priest Abiathar to his feast. They are eating and drinking with him and saying, ‘Long live King Adonijah!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he didn’t invite me or the priest Zadok or Benaiah, who is Jehoiada’s son, or your servant Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Did you allow this to happen without telling me who would sit on your throne next?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King David answered, “Call Bathsheba in here.” So she stood in front of him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and he swore an oath. He said, “I solemnly swear, as the Lord who has saved my life from all trouble lives,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will do today exactly what I swore to you by the Lord God of Israel. Your son Solomon will be king after me. He will sit on my throne.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Bathsheba bowed down with her face touching the ground in front of the king. “May Your Majesty, King David, live forever!” she said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King David said, “Summon the priest Zadok, the prophet Nathan, and Benaiah, son of Jehoiada.” So they came to the king,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and he said, “Take my officials with you. Put my son Solomon on my mule, and take him to Gihon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Have the priest Zadok and the prophet Nathan anoint him king of Israel there. Then blow the ram’s horn and say, ‘Long live King Solomon!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Follow him back here when he comes to sit on my throne. He will be king in place of me. I have appointed him to be the leader of Israel and Judah.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “So be it!” Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, answered the king. “The Lord your God says so too.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As the Lord has been with you, so may he be with Solomon. May Solomon be an even greater king than you, King David.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the priest Zadok, the prophet Nathan, Benaiah (son of Jehoiada), the Cherethites, and the Pelethites put Solomon on King David’s mule and brought him to Gihon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priest Zadok took the container of olive oil from the tent and anointed Solomon. They blew the ram’s horn, and all the people said, “Long live King Solomon!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people followed him, blew flutes, and celebrated so loudly that their voices shook the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Adonijah and all his guests heard this as they finished eating. When Joab heard the sound of the horn, he asked, “What’s the reason for the noise in the city?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was still speaking when Jonathan, son of the priest Abiathar, arrived. “Come in,” Adonijah said. “You’re an honorable man, so you must be bringing good news.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Not at all,” Jonathan answered Adonijah. “His Majesty King David has made Solomon king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king has sent the priest Zadok, the prophet Nathan, Benaiah (son of Jehoiada), the Cherethites, and the Pelethites with him. They have put him on the king’s mule.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priest Zadok and the prophet Nathan have anointed him king at Gihon. They have come from there celebrating, so the city is excited. That is the sound you heard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon is now seated on the royal throne.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Furthermore, the royal officials have come to congratulate His Majesty King David, saying, ‘May your God make Solomon’s name more famous than yours and his reign greater than your reign.’ The king himself bowed down on his bed
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and said, ‘Praise the Lord God of Israel who has let me see the heir to my throne.’ ”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Adonijah’s guests were frightened, so they got up and scattered in all directions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Adonijah was afraid of Solomon. He got up, went to the tent of meeting, and took hold of the horns of the altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Someone told Solomon, “Adonijah is afraid of you, King Solomon. He is holding on to the horns of the altar and saying, ‘Make King Solomon swear to me today that he will not have me killed.’ ”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon said, “If he will behave like an honorable man, not one hair on his head will fall to the ground. But if he does anything wrong, he will die.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon sent men to take him from the altar. Adonijah bowed down in front of King Solomon. “Go home,” Solomon told him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David was about to die, he instructed his son Solomon,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I’m about to leave this world. Be strong and mature.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Fulfill your duty to the Lord your God. Obey his directions, laws, commands, rules, and written instructions as they are recorded in Moses’ Teachings. Then you’ll succeed in everything you do wherever you may go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You’ll succeed because the Lord will keep the promise he made to me: ‘If your descendants are faithful to me with all their hearts and lives, you will never fail to have an heir on the throne of Israel.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You know what Joab (Zeruiah’s son) did to me and to the two commanders of Israel’s army—Abner, son of Ner, and Amasa, son of Jether. Joab killed them. When there was peace, he shed blood as if it were wartime. With their blood he stained the belt around his waist and the shoes on his feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Use your wisdom. Don’t let that gray-haired, old man go to his grave peacefully.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Be kind to the sons of Barzillai from Gilead. Let them eat at your table. They helped me when I was fleeing from your brother Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Shimei, son of Gera from Bahurim in Benjamin, is still with you. He cursed me repeatedly when I went to Mahanaim. But when he came to meet me at the Jordan River, I took an oath by the Lord and said, ‘As long as I’m king, I won’t have you killed.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, don’t let him go unpunished. You are wise and know what to do to him: Put that gray-haired, old man into his grave by slaughtering him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David lay down in death with his ancestors and was buried in the City of David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He ruled as king of Israel for 40 years. He ruled for 7 years in Hebron and for 33 years in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon sat on his father David’s throne, and his power was firmly established.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Adonijah, son of Haggith, went to Bathsheba, Solomon’s mother. “Is this a friendly visit?” she asked.
“Yes,” he answered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then he added, “I have a matter to discuss with you.”
“What is it?” she asked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “You know the kingship was mine. All Israel expected me to be their king. But the kingship has been turned over to my brother because the Lord gave it to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Now I want to ask you for one thing. Don’t refuse me.”
“What is it?” she asked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “Please ask King Solomon to give me Abishag from Shunem as my wife. He will not refuse you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Very well,” Bathsheba answered. “I will talk to the king for you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bathsheba went to King Solomon to talk to him on Adonijah’s behalf. The king got up to meet her and bowed down in front of her. Then he sat on his throne. He had a throne brought for his mother, and she sat at his right side.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I’m asking you for one little thing,” she said. “Don’t refuse me.”
“Ask, Mother,” the king told her. “I won’t refuse you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She replied, “Let Abishag from Shunem be given to your brother Adonijah as his wife.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon then said, “Why do you ask that Abishag from Shunem be given to Adonijah? That would be the same as giving him the kingship. After all, he is my older brother. The priest Abiathar and Joab (Zeruiah’s son) are supporting him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon took an oath by the Lord and said, “May God strike me dead if Adonijah doesn’t pay with his life for this request!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord set me on my father David’s throne and gave me a dynasty as he promised. So I solemnly swear, as the Lord who has established me lives, that Adonijah will be put to death today.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon gave this task to Benaiah, son of Jehoiada. Benaiah attacked and killed Adonijah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king told the priest Abiathar, “Go to your land in Anathoth. You deserve to die, but I won’t kill you at this time because you carried the ark of the Almighty Lord ahead of my father David and because you shared all my father’s sufferings.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Solomon removed Abiathar as the Lord’s priest and fulfilled the Lord’s word spoken at Shiloh about Eli’s family.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The news reached Joab. (He had supported Adonijah, although he hadn’t supported Absalom.) So Joab fled to the Lord’s tent and clung to the horns of the altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After King Solomon heard that Joab had fled to the altar in the tent of the Lord, Solomon sent Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, to kill Joab.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When Benaiah came to the tent of the Lord, he told Joab, “The king says, ‘Come out.’ ”
“No,” Joab answered, “I’ll die here.”
So Benaiah reported to the king what Joab had said and how he had answered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king answered, “Do as he said. Kill him, and bury him. You can remove the innocent blood—the blood which Joab shed—from me and my father’s family.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord will repay him for the slaughter he caused. Joab killed two honorable men who were better than he was. He used his sword to kill Abner (who was the son of Ner and the commander of Israel’s army) and Amasa (who was the son of Jether and the commander of Judah’s army). Joab did this without my father’s knowledge.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The responsibility for their blood will fall on Joab and his descendants forever. But may David, his descendants, family, and throne always receive peace from the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, went and attacked Joab, killed him, and buried him at his home in the desert.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king then appointed Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, to replace Joab as commander of the army. King Solomon also replaced Abiathar with the priest Zadok.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king summoned Shimei and said to him, “Build a house for yourself in Jerusalem, and stay there. Don’t leave the city to go anywhere else.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the day you leave and cross the brook in the Kidron Valley, you can be certain that you will die. You will be responsible for your own death.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Very well,” Shimei answered. “I’ll do just what Your Majesty said.”
So Shimei stayed in Jerusalem for a long time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But after three years, two of Shimei’s slaves fled to Gath’s King Achish, son of Maacah. Shimei was told that his slaves were in Gath,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: so he saddled his donkey and went to Achish in Gath to search for his slaves. Shimei went to Gath and got his slaves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Solomon heard that Shimei had gone from Jerusalem to Gath and back,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he summoned Shimei. Solomon asked him, “Didn’t I make you take an oath by the Lord? Didn’t I warn you that if you left the city to go anywhere, you could be certain that you would die? Didn’t you say to me, ‘Very well. I’ll do just what you said’?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why didn’t you keep your oath to the Lord and obey the command I gave you?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shimei, you know in your heart all the evil that you did to my father David. The Lord is going to pay you back for the evil you have done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But King Solomon is blessed, and David’s dynasty will always be firmly established by the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the king gave orders to Benaiah, son of Jehoiada. He went to attack and kill Shimei.
Solomon’s power as king was now firmly established.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon became the son-in-law of Pharaoh (the king of Egypt). After marrying Pharaoh’s daughter, Solomon brought her to the City of David until he finished building his own house, the Lord’s house, and the wall around Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people were still sacrificing at other worship sites because a temple for the name of the Lord had not yet been built.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon loved the Lord and lived by his father David’s rules. However, he still sacrificed and burned incense at these other worship sites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon went to Gibeon to sacrifice because it was the most important place of worship. Solomon sacrificed 1,000 burnt offerings on that altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In Gibeon the Lord appeared to Solomon in a dream at night. He said, “What can I give you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon responded, “You’ve shown great love to my father David, who was your servant. He lived in your presence with truth, righteousness, and commitment. And you continued to show him your great love by giving him a son to sit on his throne today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Lord my God, although I’m young and inexperienced, you’ve made me king in place of my father David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’m among your people whom you have chosen. They are too numerous to count or record.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Give me a heart that listens so that I can judge your people and tell the difference between good and evil. After all, who can judge this great people of yours?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord  was pleased that Solomon asked for this.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God replied, “You’ve asked for this and not for a long life, or riches for yourself, or the death of your enemies. Instead, you’ve asked for understanding so that you can do what is right.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I’m going to do what you’ve asked. I’m giving you a wise and understanding heart so that there will never be anyone like you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’m also giving you what you haven’t asked for—riches and honor—so that no other king will be like you as long as you live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And if you follow me and obey my laws and commands as your father David did, then I will also give you a long life.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon woke up and realized it had been a dream. He went to Jerusalem and stood in front of the ark of the Lord’s promise. He sacrificed burnt offerings and fellowship offerings and held a banquet for all his officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A short time later two prostitutes came to the king and stood in front of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One woman said to him, “Sir, this woman and I live in the same house. I gave birth to a son while she was with me in the house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Two days later this woman also gave birth to a son. We were alone. No one else was with us. Just the two of us were in the house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That night this woman’s son died because she rolled over on top of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So she got up during the night and took my son, who was beside me, while I was asleep. She held him in her arms. Then she laid her dead son in my arms.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When I got up in the morning to nurse my son, he was dead! I took a good look at him and realized that he wasn’t my son at all!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The other woman said, “No! My son is alive—your son is dead.”
The first woman kept on saying, “No! Your son is dead—my son is alive.” So they argued in front of the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said, “This one keeps saying, ‘My son is alive—your son is dead,’ and that one keeps saying, ‘No! Your son is dead—my son is alive.’ ”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king told his servants to bring him a sword. When they brought it,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he said, “Cut the living child in two. Give half to the one and half to the other.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the woman whose son was still alive was deeply moved by her love for the child. She said to the king, “Please, sir, give her the living child. Please don’t kill him!”
But the other woman said, “He won’t be mine or yours. Cut him in two.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king replied, “Give the living child to the first woman. Don’t kill him. She is his mother.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All Israel heard about the decision the king made. They respected the king very highly, because they saw he possessed wisdom from God to do what was right.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When King Solomon was the king of all Israel,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
these were his officials:
Azariah, son of Zadok, was the chief priest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Elihoreph and Ahijah, the sons of Shisha, were scribes.
Jehoshaphat, son of Ahilud, was the royal historian.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, was commander of the army.
Zadok and Abiathar were priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Azariah, son of Nathan, was in charge of the district governors.
Zabud, son of Nathan, was the king’s adviser.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Ahishar was in charge of the palace.
Adoniram, son of Abda, was in charge of forced labor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon appointed 12 district governors in Israel. They were to provide food for the king and his palace. Each one had to supply food for one month every year.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Their names were
Benhur, who was in charge of the hills of Ephraim,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bendeker, who was in charge of Makaz, Shaalbim, Beth Shemesh, and Elon Beth Hanan, and
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Benhesed, who was in charge of Arubboth, Socoh, and the entire region of Hepher.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Benabinadab had the entire region of Dor.
(Solomon’s daughter Taphath was his wife.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Baana, son of Ahilud, had Taanach, Megiddo, and all of Beth Shean.
(This was near Zarethan, below Jezreel, from Beth Shean to Abel Meholah and over to Jokmeam.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Bengeber was in charge of Ramoth Gilead; he had the settlements of Jair, a descendant of Manasseh, in Gilead.
He also had the territory of Argob in Bashan, 60 large cities with walls and bronze bars across their gates.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahinadab, son of Iddo, was in charge of Mahanaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Ahimaaz was in charge of Naphtali.
(He also married Solomon’s daughter Basemath.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Baana, son of Hushai, was in charge of Asher and Aloth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat, son of Paruah, was in charge of Issachar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shimei, son of Ela, was in charge of Benjamin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Geber, son of Uri, was in charge of Gilead, the territory of King Sihon the Amorite and King Og of Bashan. (There was only one governor in that territory.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Judah and Israel were as numerous as the sand on the seashore. They ate and drank and lived happily.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon ruled all the kingdoms from the Euphrates River to the country of the Philistines and as far as the Egyptian border. These kingdoms paid taxes and were subject to Solomon as long as he lived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon’s food supply for one day was 180 bushels of flour, 360 bushels of coarse flour,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: 10 fattened cows, 20 cows from the pasture, and 100 sheep in addition to deer, gazelles, fallow deer, and fattened birds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He controlled all the territory west of the Euphrates River from Tiphsah to Gaza and all of its kings. So he lived in peace with all the neighboring countries.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As long as Solomon lived, Judah and Israel (from Dan to Beersheba) lived securely, everyone under his own vine and fig tree.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon had stalls for 40,000 chariot horses. He also had 12,000 chariot soldiers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each of the governors provided food for one month every year for King Solomon and all who ate at his table. The governors saw to it that nothing was in short supply.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They brought their quota of barley and straw for the chariot horses to the proper places.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God gave Solomon wisdom—keen insight and a mind as limitless as the sand on the seashore.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon’s wisdom was greater than that of all the eastern people and all the wisdom of the Egyptians.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was wiser than anyone, than Ethan the Ezrahite, or Heman, Calcol, or Darda, Mahol’s sons. His fame spread to all the nations around him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon spoke 3,000 proverbs and wrote 1,005 songs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He described and classified trees—from the cedar in Lebanon to the hyssop growing out of the wall. He described and classified animals, birds, reptiles, and fish.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: People came from every nation to hear his wisdom; they came from all the kings of the earth who had heard about his wisdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Hiram of Tyre sent his officials to Solomon when he heard that Solomon had been anointed king to succeed his father. Hiram had always been David’s friend.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon sent word to Hiram, by saying,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You know that my father David was surrounded by war. He couldn’t build a temple for the name of the Lord our God until the Lord let him defeat his enemies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord my God has surrounded me with peace. I have no rival and no trouble.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now I’m thinking of building a temple for the name of the Lord my God as the Lord spoke to my father David: ‘Your son, whom I will put on your throne to succeed you, will build a temple for my name.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So order men to cut down cedars from Lebanon for me. My workers will work with your workers. I will pay you whatever wages you ask for your workers. You know we don’t have any skilled lumberjacks like those from Sidon.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hiram was very glad to hear what Solomon had said. Hiram responded, “May the Lord be praised today. He has given David a wise son to rule this great nation.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hiram sent men to Solomon to say, “I’ve received the message you sent me. I will do everything you want in regard to the cedar and cypress logs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My workers will bring logs from Lebanon to the sea, and I will have them make them into rafts to go by sea to any place you specify. There I will have them taken apart, and you can use them. You can pay me by providing food for my palace.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Hiram gave Solomon all the cedar and cypress wood he wanted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon gave Hiram 120,000 bushels of wheat and 120,000 gallons of pure olive oil. Solomon paid Hiram this much every year.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord gave Solomon wisdom as he had promised. There was peace between Hiram and Solomon, and they made a treaty with one another.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon forced 30,000 men from all over Israel to work for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He sent a shift of 10,000 men to Lebanon for a month. They would spend one month in Lebanon and two months at home. Adoniram was in charge of forced labor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon had 70,000 men who carried heavy loads, 70,000 who quarried stone in the mountains,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and 3,300 foremen who were in charge of the workers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king commanded them to quarry large, expensive blocks of stone in order to provide a foundation of cut stone for the temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon’s workmen, Hiram’s workmen, and men from Gebal quarried the stone and prepared the logs and stone to build the temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon began to build the Lord’s temple 480 years after Israel left Egypt. He began building in the month of Ziv (the second month) of the fourth year of his reign over Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The temple that King Solomon built for the Lord was 90 feet long, 30 feet wide, and 45 feet high.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entrance hall in front of the main room of the temple was the same length as the shorter side of the temple. It extended 15 feet in front of the temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also made latticed windows for the temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He built an annex containing side rooms all around the temple. This annex was next to the walls of the main building and the inner sanctuary.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The interior of the lowest story of the annex was 7½ feet wide, the second story was 9 feet wide, and the third story was 10½ feet wide. Solomon made ledges all around the temple so that this annex would not be fastened to the walls of the temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The temple was built with stone blocks that were finished at the quarry. No hammer, chisel, or any other iron tool made a sound at the temple construction site.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entrance to the first story  was on the south side of the temple. A staircase went up to the middle story and then to the third story.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he had finished building the walls, he roofed the temple with rows of cedar beams and planks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He built each story of the annex 7½ feet high alongside the entire temple. Its cedar beams were attached to the temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord spoke to Solomon, saying,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This concerns the temple you are building: If you live by my laws, follow my rules, and keep my commands, I will fulfill the promise I made about you to your father David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will live among the Israelites and never abandon my people.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Solomon had finished building the temple’s frame,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he began to line the inside walls of the temple with cedar boards. He paneled the inside of the temple with wood from floor to ceiling. He covered the floor of the temple with cypress planks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He sectioned off a 30-foot-long room at the rear of the temple with cedar boards from the floor to the rafters. He built it to serve as an inner room, the most holy place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The 60-foot-long room at the front of the temple served as the main hall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gourds and flowers were carved into the cedar paneling inside the temple. Everything was covered with cedar. No stone could be seen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He prepared the inner room of the temple in order to put the ark of the Lord’s promise there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The inner room was 30 feet long, 30 feet wide, and 30 feet high. Solomon covered it and the cedar altar with pure gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He covered the inside of the temple with pure gold. He put golden chains across the front of the inner room which was covered with gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He covered the entire inside of the temple with gold. He also covered the entire altar in the inner room with gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the inner room he made two 15-foot-tall angels  out of olive wood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each wing of the angels was 7½ feet long. The distance from the tip of one wing to the tip of the other was 15 feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Both angels had a 15-foot wingspan. Both had the same measurements and the same shape.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each was 15 feet high.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon put the angels in the inner room of the temple. The wings of the angels extended so that the wing of one of the angels touched the one wall, and the wing of the other touched the other wall. Their remaining wings touched each other in the center of the room.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He covered the angels with gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He carved angels, palm trees, and flowers into the walls all around the inner and outer rooms of the temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He covered the floor of the inner and outer rooms of the temple with gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made doors for the entrance to the inner room out of olive wood. The doorposts had five sides.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The two doors were made out of olive wood. He carved angels, palm trees, and flowers into them and covered them with gold. The gold was hammered onto the angels and the palm trees.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the same way he made square doorposts out of olive wood for the temple’s entrance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made two doors from cypress. Each of the doors had two folding panels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On them he carved angels, palm trees, and flowers. He evenly covered them with gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He built the inner courtyard with three courses of finished stones and a course of finished cedar beams.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the month of Ziv of the fourth year of Solomon’s reign, the foundation of the Lord’s temple was laid.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the month of Bul (the eighth month) of the eleventh year of his reign, the temple was finished according to all its plans and specifications. He spent seven years building it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon took 13 years to finish building his palace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He built a hall named the Forest of Lebanon. It was 150 feet long, 75 feet wide, and 45 feet high. It had four rows of cedar pillars supporting cedar beams.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The hall was covered with cedar above the side rooms, which were supported by 45 pillars (15 per row).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The windows were in three rows facing each other on opposite sides of the palace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the doors and doorframes were square. There were three doors facing each other on opposite sides of the palace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon made the Hall of Pillars 75 feet long and 45 feet wide. In front of the hall was an entrance hall with pillars.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made the Hall of Justice, where he sat on his throne and served as judge. The hall was covered with cedar from floor to ceiling.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His own private quarters were in a different location than the Hall of Justice, but they were similar in design. Solomon also built private quarters like this for his wife, Pharaoh’s daughter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From the foundation to the roof, all these buildings, including the large courtyard, were built with high-grade stone blocks. The stone blocks were cut to size and trimmed with saws on their inner and outer faces.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The foundation was made with large, high-grade stones (some 12 feet long, others 15 feet long).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Above the foundation were cedar beams and high-grade stone blocks, which had been cut to size.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The large courtyard had three layers of cut stone blocks and a layer of cedar beams, like the inner courtyard of the Lord’s temple and the entrance hall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon had Hiram brought from Tyre.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hiram was the son of a widow from the tribe of Naphtali. His father, a native of Tyre, was a skilled bronze craftsman. Hiram was highly skilled, resourceful, and knowledgeable about all kinds of bronze craftsmanship. He came to King Solomon and did all his bronze work.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made two bronze pillars. Each was 27 feet high and 18 feet in circumference.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made two capitals of cast bronze to put on top of the pillars. Each capital was 7½ feet high.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also made seven rows of filigree and chains for each capital.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After he made the pillars, he made two rows of decorations around the filigree to cover the capitals which were above the pillars. He made the capitals identical to each other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The capitals on top of the pillars in the entrance hall were lily-shaped. Each was six feet high.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Two hundred pomegranates in rows were directly above the bowl-shaped parts around the filigree on the capitals on both pillars.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hiram set up the pillars in the temple’s entrance hall. He set up the pillar on the right and named it Jachin [He Establishes]. Then he set up the pillar on the left and named it Boaz [In Him Is Strength].
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were lily-shaped capitals at the top of the pillars. He finished the work on the pillars.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hiram made a pool from cast metal. It was 15 feet in diameter. It was round, 7½ feet high, and had a circumference of 45 feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Under the rim were two rows of gourds all around the 45-foot circumference of the pool. They were cast in metal when the pool was cast.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The pool was set on 12 metal bulls. Three bulls faced north, three faced west, three faced south, and three faced east. The pool was set on them, and their hindquarters were toward the center of the pool.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The pool was three inches thick. Its rim was like the rim of a cup, shaped like a lily’s bud. It held 12,000 gallons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made ten bronze stands. Each stand was 6 feet square and 4½ feet high.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The stands were made this way: They had side panels set in frames.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the panels set in frames were lions, oxen, and angels. These were also on the frames. Above and below the lions and the cattle were engraved designs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each stand had four bronze wheels on bronze axles and four supports beneath the basin. The supports were made of cast metal with designs on the sides.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each had a 1½-foot-deep opening in the center to the circular frame on top. The opening was round, formed like a pedestal, and was two feet wide. Around the opening there were engravings. But the panels were square, not round.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The four wheels were under the panels, and the axles were attached to the stand. Each wheel was two feet high.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The wheels were made like chariot wheels. The axles, rims, spokes, and hubs were all cast metal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The four supports at the four corners of each stand were part of the stand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The top of each stand had a round, nine-inch-high band. Above the stand were supports which were part of the panels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hiram engraved angels, lions, palm trees, and designs in every available space on the supports and panels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the way he made the ten stands. All of them were cast in the same mold, identical in size and shape.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hiram also made ten bronze basins. Each basin held 240 gallons. Every basin was six feet wide. There was one basin on each of the ten stands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He put five stands on the south side of the temple and five on the north side of the temple. He set the pool on the south side of the temple in the southeast corner.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Hiram also made pots, shovels, and bowls.
So Hiram finished all the work for King Solomon on the Lord’s temple:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: 2 pillars, the bowl-shaped capitals on top of the 2 pillars, and 2 sets of filigree to cover the 2 bowl-shaped capitals on top of the pillars,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: 400 pomegranates for the 2 sets of filigree (2 rows of pomegranates for each filigree to cover the 2 bowl-shaped capitals on the pillars),
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: 10 stands and 10 basins on the stands,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: 1 pool, 12 bulls under the pool,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: pots, shovels, and bowls. Hiram made all these utensils out of polished bronze for the Lord’s temple at King Solomon’s request.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king cast them in foundries in the Jordan Valley between Succoth and Zarethan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon left all the products unweighed because so much bronze was used. No one tried to determine how much the bronze weighed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon made all the furnishings for the Lord’s temple: the gold altar, the gold table on which the bread of the presence was placed,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: lamp stands of pure gold (five on the south side and five on the north in front of the inner room), flowers, lamps, gold tongs,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: dishes, snuffers, bowls, saucers, incense burners of pure gold, the gold sockets for the doors of the inner room (the most holy place), and the doors of the temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the work King Solomon did on the Lord’s temple was finished. He brought the holy things that had belonged to his father David—the silver, gold, and utensils—and put them in the storerooms of the Lord’s temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Solomon assembled the respected leaders of Israel, all the heads of the tribes, and the leaders of the Israelite families. They came to King Solomon in Jerusalem to take the ark of the Lord’s promise from the City of David (that is, Zion).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people of Israel gathered around King Solomon at the Festival of Booths in the month of Ethanim, the seventh month.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all the leaders of Israel had arrived, the priests picked up the Lord’s ark.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They brought the ark, the tent of meeting, and all the holy utensils in it to the temple. The priests and the Levites carried them
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: while King Solomon with the whole assembly from Israel were offering countless sheep and cattle sacrifices in front of the ark.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests brought the ark of the Lord’s promise to its place in the inner room of the temple (the most holy place) under the wings of the angels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the angels’ outstretched wings were over the place where the ark rested, the angels became a covering above the ark and its poles.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The poles were so long that their ends could be seen in the holy place by anyone standing in front of the inner room, but they couldn’t be seen outside. (They are still there today.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was nothing in the ark except the two stone tablets Moses put there at Horeb, where the Lord made a promise to the Israelites after they left Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the priests left the holy place, a cloud filled the Lord’s temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests couldn’t serve because of the cloud. The Lord’s glory filled his temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Solomon said, “The Lord said he would live in a dark cloud.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I certainly have built you a high temple, a home for you to live in permanently.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king turned around and blessed the whole assembly of Israel while they were standing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Thanks be to the Lord God of Israel. With his mouth he made a promise to my father David; with his hand he carried it out. He said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Ever since I brought my people Israel out of Egypt, I didn’t choose any city in any of the tribes of Israel as a place to build a temple for my name. But now I’ve chosen David to rule my people Israel.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “My father David had his heart set on building a temple for the name of the Lord God of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, the Lord said to my father David, ‘Since you had your heart set on building a temple for my name, your intentions were good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But you must not build the temple. Instead, your own son will build the temple for my name.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord has kept the promise he made. I have taken my father David’s place, and I sit on the throne of Israel as the Lord promised. I’ve built the temple for the name of the Lord God of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ve made a place there for the ark which contains the Lord’s promise that he made to our ancestors when he brought them out of Egypt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the presence of the entire assembly of Israel, Solomon stood in front of the Lord’s altar. He stretched out his hands toward heaven
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and said,
“Lord God of Israel,
there is no god like you in heaven above or on earth below.
You keep your promise  of mercy to your servants,
who obey you wholeheartedly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You have kept your promise to my father David, your servant.
With your mouth you promised it.
With your hand you carried it out as it is today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Now, Lord God of Israel,
keep your promise to my father David, your servant.
You said, ‘You will never fail to have an heir
sitting in front of me on the throne of Israel
if your descendants are faithful to me
as you have been faithful to me.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“So now, God of Israel,
may the promise you made to my father David,
your servant, come true.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Does God really live on earth?
If heaven itself, the highest heaven, cannot hold you,
then how can this temple that I have built?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Nevertheless, my Lord God, please pay attention to my prayer for mercy.
Listen to my cry for help as I pray to you today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Night and day may your eyes be on this temple,
the place about which you said, ‘My name will be there.’
Listen to me as I pray toward this place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Hear the plea for mercy
that your people Israel and I pray toward this place.
Hear us when we pray to heaven, the place where you live.
Hear and forgive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“If anyone sins against another person
and is required to take an oath
and comes to take the oath in front of your altar in this temple,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
then hear that person in heaven, take action, and make a decision.
Condemn the guilty person with the proper punishment,
but declare the innocent person innocent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“An enemy may defeat your people Israel
because they have sinned against you.
But when your people turn to you, praise your name, pray,
and plead with you in this temple,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
then hear them in heaven, forgive the sins of your people Israel,
and bring them back to the land that you gave to their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“When the sky is shut and there’s no rain
because they are sinning against you,
and they pray toward this place, praise your name,
and turn away from their sin because you made them suffer,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
then hear them in heaven.
Forgive the sins of your servants, your people Israel.
Teach them the proper way to live.
Then send rain on the land,
which you gave to your people as an inheritance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“There may be famine in the land.
Plant diseases, heat waves, funguses, locusts,
or grasshoppers may destroy crops.
Enemies may blockade Israel’s city gates.
During every plague or sickness
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
hear every prayer for mercy,
made by one person or by all the people in Israel,
whose consciences bother them,
who stretch out their hands toward this temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Hear them in heaven, where you live.
Forgive them, and take action.
Give each person the proper reply.
(You know what is in their hearts,
because you alone know what is in the hearts of all people.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then, as long as they live in the land that you gave to our ancestors,
they will fear you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“People will hear about your great name,
mighty hand, and powerful arm.
So when people who are not Israelites
come from distant countries because of your name
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: to pray facing this temple,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
hear them in heaven, the place where you live.
Do everything they ask you
so that all the people of the world may know your name
and fear you like your people Israel
and learn also that this temple which I built bears your name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“When your people go to war against their enemies
(wherever you may send them)
and they pray to you, O Lord, toward the city you have chosen
and the temple I built for your name,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
then hear their prayer for mercy in heaven,
and do what is right for them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“They may sin against you.
(No one is sinless.)
You may become angry with them and hand them over to an enemy
who takes them to another country as captives,
whether it is far or near.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If they come to their senses,
are sorry for what they’ve done,
and plead with you in the land where they are captives,
saying, ‘We have sinned. We have done wrong.
We have been wicked,’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
if they change their attitude toward you
in the land of their enemies where they are captives,
if they pray to you
toward the land that you gave their ancestors,
and the city you have chosen,
and the temple I have built for your name,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
then in heaven, the place where you live, hear their prayer for mercy.
Do what is right for them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Forgive your people, who have sinned against you.
Forgive all their wrongs when they rebelled against you,
and cause those who captured them to have mercy on them
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because they are your own people
whom you brought out of Egypt
from the middle of an iron smelter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“May your eyes always see my plea and your people Israel’s plea
so that you will listen to them whenever they call on you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
After all, you, Lord God, set them apart from all the people of the world
to be your own as you promised through your servant Moses
when you brought our ancestors out of Egypt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Solomon finished praying this prayer for mercy to the Lord, he stood in front of the Lord’s altar, where he had been kneeling with his hands stretched out toward heaven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he stood and in a loud voice blessed the entire assembly of Israel,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Thanks be to the Lord! He has given his people Israel rest, as he had promised. None of the good promises he made through his servant Moses has failed to come true.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May the Lord our God be with us as he was with our ancestors. May he never leave us or abandon us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May he bend our hearts toward him. Then we will follow him and keep his commands, laws, and rules, which he commanded our ancestors to keep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May these words which I have prayed to the Lord be near the Lord our God day and night. Then he will give me and his people Israel justice every day as it is needed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In this way all the people of the world will know that the Lord is God and there is no other god.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May your hearts be committed to the Lord our God. Then you will live by his laws and keep his commands as you have today.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king and all Israel offered sacrifices to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon sacrificed 22,000 cattle and 120,000 sheep as fellowship offerings to the Lord. So the king and all the people of Israel dedicated the Lord’s temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On that day the king designated the courtyard in front of the Lord’s temple as a holy place. He sacrificed the burnt offerings, grain offerings, and the fat from the fellowship offerings because the bronze altar in front of the Lord was too small to hold all of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time Solomon and all Israel celebrated the Festival of Booths. A large crowd had come from the territory between the border of Hamath and the River of Egypt to be near the Lord our God for seven days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the eighth day he dismissed the people. They blessed the king and went to their tents. They rejoiced with cheerful hearts for all the blessings the Lord had given his servant David and his people Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon finished building the Lord’s temple, the royal palace, and everything else he wanted to build.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord appeared to him a second time, as he had appeared to him in Gibeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord said to him,
“I have heard your prayer for mercy that you made to me.
I have declared that this temple which you have built is holy
so that my name may be placed there forever.
My eyes and my heart will always be there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“If you will be faithful to me as your father David was
(with a sincere and upright heart),
do everything I command,
and keep my laws and rules,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
then I will establish your royal dynasty over Israel forever
as I promised your father David when I said,
‘You will never fail to have an heir on the throne of Israel.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But if you and your descendants dare to turn away from me
and do not keep my commands and laws that I gave to you,
and follow and serve other gods and worship them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
then I will cut Israel out of the land I gave them.
I will reject this temple that I declared holy for my name.
Israel will be an example
and an object of ridicule for all the people of the world.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Everyone passing by this temple, as impressive as it is, will be appalled.
They will gasp and ask,
‘Why did the Lord do these things to this land and this temple?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They will answer themselves,
‘They abandoned the Lord their God,
who brought their ancestors out of Egypt.
They adopted other gods, worshiped, and served them.
That is why the Lord brought this disaster on them.’ ”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It took Solomon 20 years to build the two houses (the Lord’s house and the royal palace).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When King Solomon had finished, he gave King Hiram of Tyre 20 cities in Galilee. (Hiram had supplied Solomon with as much cedar and cypress lumber and gold as he wanted.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hiram left Tyre to see the cities Solomon gave him. However, they didn’t please him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “What kind of cities have you given me, brother?” he asked. So he named it the region of Cabul [Good for Nothing]. (They’re still called that today.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hiram had sent the king 9,000 pounds of gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the record of the forced laborers whom King Solomon drafted to build the Lord’s house, his own house, the Millo, the walls of Jerusalem, and the cities of Hazor, Megiddo, and Gezer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (The king of Egypt captured Gezer, burned it down, and killed the Canaanites living there. Then he gave it to his daughter, Solomon’s wife, as a wedding present.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Solomon rebuilt Gezer, Lower Beth Horon,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Baalath, Tadmor in the desert (inside the country), and
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: all the storage cities that he owned. He also built cities for his chariots, cities for his war horses, and whatever else he wanted to build in Jerusalem, Lebanon, or the entire territory that he governed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Amorites, Hittites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites had been left in the land because the Israelites had not been able to claim them for God by destroying them. They were not Israelites,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but they had descendants who were still in the land. Solomon drafted them for slave labor. (They are still slaves today.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Solomon didn’t make any of the Israelites slaves. Instead, they were soldiers, officials, officers, generals, and commanders of his chariot and cavalry units.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the officers in charge of Solomon’s projects: 550 foremen for the people who did the work.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh’s daughter moved from the City of David to the palace that Solomon had built for her. Then he built the Millo.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Three times a year Solomon sacrificed burnt offerings and fellowship offerings on the altar he built for the Lord. He burnt them on the altar that was in the Lord’s presence. And he finished the temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon also built a fleet near the Red Sea coast at Ezion Geber by Elath in Edom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hiram sent his own servants who were experienced seamen with the fleet. Along with Solomon’s servants
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: they went to Ophir, got 31,500 pounds of gold, and brought it to King Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The queen of Sheba heard about Solomon’s reputation. (He owed his reputation to the name of the Lord.) So she came to test him with riddles.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She arrived in Jerusalem with a large group of servants, with camels carrying spices, a very large quantity of gold, and precious stones. When she came to Solomon, she talked to him about everything she had on her mind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon answered all her questions. No question was too difficult for the king to answer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the queen of Sheba saw all of Solomon’s wisdom, the palace he built,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the food on his table, his officers’ seating arrangement, the organization of his officials and the uniforms they wore, his cupbearers, and the burnt offerings that he sacrificed at the Lord’s temple, she was breathless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She told the king, “What I heard in my country about your words and your wisdom is true!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I didn’t believe the reports until I came and saw it with my own eyes. I wasn’t even told half of it. Your wisdom and wealth surpass the stories I’ve heard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: How blessed your men must be! How blessed these servants of yours must be because they are always stationed in front of you, listening to your wisdom!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thank the Lord your God, who is pleased with you. He has put you on the throne of Israel. Because of your God’s eternal love for the people of Israel, he has made you king so that you would maintain justice and righteousness.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She gave the king 9,000 pounds of gold, a very large quantity of spices, and precious stones. Never again was such a large quantity of spices brought into Israel as those that the queen of Sheba gave King Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hiram’s fleet that brought gold from Ophir also brought a large quantity of sandalwood and precious stones from Ophir.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: With the sandalwood the king made supports for the Lord’s temple and the royal palace, and lyres and harps for the singers. Never again was sandalwood like this imported into Israel, nor has any been seen there to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon gave the queen of Sheba anything she wanted, whatever she asked for, besides what he had given her out of his royal generosity. Then she and her servants went back to her country.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The gold that came to Solomon in one year weighed 49,950 pounds,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: not counting the gold which came from the merchants, the traders’ profits, all the Arab kings, and the governors of the country.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon made 200 large shields of hammered gold, using 15 pounds of gold on each shield.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also made 300 small shields of hammered gold, using four pounds of gold on each shield. The king put them in the hall which he called the Forest of Lebanon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king also made a large ivory throne and covered it with fine gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Six steps led to the throne. Carved into the back of the throne was a calf’s head. There were armrests on both sides of the seat. Two lions stood beside the armrests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Twelve lions stood on six steps, one on each side. Nothing like this had been made for any other kingdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All King Solomon’s cups were gold, and all the utensils for the hall which he called the Forest of Lebanon were fine gold. (Nothing was silver, because it wasn’t considered valuable in Solomon’s time.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king had a fleet headed for Tarshish with Hiram’s fleet. Once every three years the Tarshish fleet would bring gold, silver, ivory, apes, and monkeys.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In wealth and wisdom King Solomon was greater than all the other kings of the world.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The whole world wanted to listen to the wisdom that God gave Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So everyone who came brought him gifts: articles of silver and gold, clothing, weapons, spices, horses, and mules. This happened year after year.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon built up his army with chariots and war horses. He had 1,400 chariots and 12,000 war horses. He stationed some in chariot cities and others with himself in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king made silver as common in Jerusalem as stones, and he made cedars as plentiful as fig trees in the foothills.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon’s horses were imported from Egypt and Kue. The king’s traders bought them from Kue for a fixed price.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each chariot was imported from Egypt for 15 pounds of silver and each horse for 6 ounces of silver. For the same price they obtained horses to export to all the Hittite and Aramean kings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon loved many foreign women in addition to Pharaoh’s daughter. He loved Hittite women and women from Moab, Ammon, Edom, and Sidon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They came from the nations about which the Lord had said to the people of Israel, “Never intermarry with them. They will surely tempt you to follow their gods.” But Solomon was obsessed with their love.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had 700 wives who were princesses and 300 wives who were concubines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In his old age, his wives tempted him to follow other gods. He was no longer committed to the Lord his God as his father David had been.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon followed Astarte (the goddess of the Sidonians) and Milcom (the disgusting idol of the Ammonites).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Solomon did what the Lord considered evil. He did not wholeheartedly follow the Lord as his father David had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Solomon built an illegal worship site on the hill east of Jerusalem for Chemosh (the disgusting idol of Moab) and for Molech (the disgusting idol of the Ammonites).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did these things for each of his foreign wives who burned incense and sacrificed to their gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord became angry with Solomon because his heart had turned from the Lord God of Israel, who had appeared to him twice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God had given him commands about this. He told him not to follow other gods. But Solomon did not obey God’s command.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord told Solomon, “Because this is your attitude and you have no respect for my promises  or my laws that I commanded you to keep, I will certainly tear the kingdom away from you. I will give it to one of your servants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I will not do it in your lifetime because of your father David. I will tear it away from the hands of your son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, I will not tear the whole kingdom away from you. I will give your son one tribe for my servant David’s sake and for the sake of Jerusalem, the city that I chose.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord raised up Hadad the Edomite as a rival to Solomon. Hadad was from the Edomite royal family.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David had conquered Edom, Joab, the commander of the army, went to bury those killed in battle and killed every male in Edom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (Joab and all Israel stayed there six months until they had destroyed every male in Edom.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hadad was a young boy at the time. He and some of his father’s Edomite servants fled to Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They left Midian and went to Paran. Taking some men from Paran with them, they went to Pharaoh (the king of Egypt). Pharaoh gave Hadad a home, a food allowance, and land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh approved of Hadad. So he gave Hadad his sister-in-law, the sister of Queen Tahpenes, to be Hadad’s wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tahpenes’ sister had a son named Genubath. Tahpenes presented the boy to Pharaoh in the palace, and Genubath lived in the palace among Pharaoh’s children.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Hadad heard in Egypt that David had lain down in death with his ancestors and that Joab, the commander of the army, had died, he said to Pharaoh, “Let me go to my own country.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Pharaoh asked him, “What don’t you have here that makes you eager to go home?”
“Nothing,” he said. “But let me leave anyway.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God also raised up Rezon, son of Eliada, as a rival to Solomon. Rezon fled from his master, King Hadadezer of Zobah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: after David killed the men of Zobah. Rezon gathered men and became the leader of a troop of warriors. They went to Damascus, settled there, and ruled a kingdom in Damascus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In addition to the trouble that Hadad caused, Rezon was Israel’s rival as long as Solomon lived. He ruled Aram and despised Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was also Jeroboam, who was the son of Nebat and an Ephrathite from Zeredah. His mother Zeruah was a widow. He was one of Solomon’s officers, but he rebelled against the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This was the situation when he rebelled against the king: Solomon was building the Millo  and repairing a break in the wall of the City of David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon saw that Jeroboam was a very able and hardworking man. So he put Jeroboam in charge of all forced labor from the tribes of Joseph.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time Jeroboam left Jerusalem. The prophet Ahijah from Shiloh met him on the road. The two of them were alone in the open country, and Ahijah had on new clothes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahijah took his new garment and tore it into 12 pieces.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He told Jeroboam, “Take 10 pieces because this is what the Lord God of Israel says: I am going to tear the kingdom out of Solomon’s hands and give ten tribes to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will have one tribe left because of my servant David and Jerusalem, the city I have chosen from all the tribes of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will do this because he has abandoned me and worshiped Astarte (the goddess of the Sidonians), Chemosh (the god of Moab), and Milcom (the god of Ammon). He has not followed my ways. He did not do what I consider right or keep my laws and decrees as his father David did.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I will not take the whole kingdom from him. Instead, I will allow him to be ruler as long as he lives because of my servant David whom I chose, who obeyed my commands and laws.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I will take the kingdom away from his son and give you ten tribes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will give his son one tribe so that my servant David will always have a lamp in my presence in Jerusalem, the city where I chose to place my name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I will choose you so that you can rule everything you desire. You will be king of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you will do all I command you, follow my ways, and do what I consider right by obeying my laws and commands as my servant David did, then I will be with you. I will build a permanent dynasty for you as I did for David. And I will give you Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will make David’s descendants suffer for this, but not always.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Solomon tried to kill Jeroboam, but Jeroboam fled to King Shishak of Egypt. He stayed in Egypt until Solomon died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Aren’t the rest of Solomon’s acts—everything he did—and his wisdom written in the records of Solomon?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The length of Solomon’s reign in Jerusalem over all Israel was 40 years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon lay down in death with his ancestors and was buried in the City of David. His son Rehoboam succeeded him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rehoboam went to Shechem because all Israel had gone to Shechem to make him king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeroboam (Nebat’s son) was still in Egypt, where he had fled from King Solomon. When he heard about Rehoboam, he returned from Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel sent for Jeroboam and invited him back. Jeroboam and the entire assembly of Israel went to speak to Rehoboam. They said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Your father made us carry a heavy burden. Reduce the hard work and lighten the heavy burden he put on us, and we will serve you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to them, “Leave and come back the day after tomorrow.” So the people left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Rehoboam sought advice from the older leaders who had served his father Solomon while he was still alive. He asked, “What do you advise? How should I respond to these people?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They told him, “If you will serve these people today, humble yourself, and speak gently, then they will always be your servants.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he ignored the advice the older leaders gave him. He sought advice from the young men who had grown up with him and were serving him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He asked them, “What is your advice? How should we respond to these people who are asking me to lighten the burden my father put on them?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The young men who had grown up with him answered, “This is what you should tell them: ‘My little finger is heavier than my father’s whole body.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If my father put a heavy burden on you, I will add to it. If my father punished you with whips, I will punish you with scorpions.’ ”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jeroboam and all the people came back to Rehoboam two days later, as the king had instructed them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king answered the people harshly. He ignored the advice the older leaders gave him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He spoke to them as the young men advised. He said, “If my father made your burden heavy, I will add to it. If my father punished you with whips, I will punish you with scorpions.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king refused to listen to the people because the Lord was directing these events to carry out the promise he had made to Jeroboam (Nebat’s son) through Ahijah from Shiloh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When all Israel saw that the king refused to listen to them, the people answered the king,
“What share do we have in David’s kingdom?
We won’t receive an inheritance from Jesse’s son.
To your own tents, Israel!
Now look after your own house, David!”
So Israel went home to their own tents.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Rehoboam ruled the Israelites who lived in the cities of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King Rehoboam sent Adoram to Israel. He was in charge of forced labor, but they stoned him to death. So King Rehoboam got on his chariot as fast as he could and fled to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel has rebelled against David’s dynasty to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all Israel heard that Jeroboam had returned, they sent men to invite him to the assembly. They made him king of all Israel. Only the tribe of Judah remained loyal to David’s dynasty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Rehoboam came to Jerusalem, he gathered all the people of Judah and the tribe of Benjamin, 180,000 of the best soldiers, to fight against the people of Israel and return the kingdom to Rehoboam, son of Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But God spoke his word to Shemaiah, the man of God. He said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Speak to Judah’s King Rehoboam, son of Solomon, and all the people of Judah and Benjamin, and the rest of the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord says: Don’t wage war against your relatives from Israel. Everyone, go home. What has happened is my doing.” So they obeyed the Lord’s word. They returned home, as the Lord told them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeroboam rebuilt Shechem in the hills of Ephraim and lived there. Then he left that place and built Penuel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to himself, “The kingdom will probably return to David’s dynasty now.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Rehoboam of Judah, the former master of these people, will regain popularity if they go to sacrifice in the Lord’s temple in Jerusalem. Then they will kill me and return to King Rehoboam of Judah.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After seeking advice, the king made two golden calves. He said, “You’ve been worshiping in Jerusalem long enough. Israel, here are your gods who brought you out of Egypt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He put one in Bethel and the other in Dan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Worshiping them became Israel’s sin. The people went as far as Dan to worship the one calf.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeroboam built worship sites on hilltops. He appointed men who were not descended from Levi to be priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator
