verses.text: Jeroboam appointed a festival on the fifteenth day of the eighth month, just like the festival in Judah. He went to the altar in Bethel to sacrifice to the calves he had made. He appointed priests from the illegal worship sites to serve in Bethel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He went to his altar in Bethel to burn an offering on the fifteenth day of the eighth month, the festival he had invented for the Israelites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A man of God from Judah had come to Bethel. When he arrived, Jeroboam was standing at the altar to offer a sacrifice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: By a command of the Lord, this man condemned the altar. “Altar, altar! This is what the Lord says: There will be a son born in David’s family line. His name will be Josiah. Here on you Josiah will sacrifice the priests from the illegal worship sites who offer sacrifices on you. Human bones will be burned on you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That day the man of God also gave them a miraculous sign, saying, “This is the sign that the Lord will give you: You will see the altar torn apart. The ashes on it will be poured on the ground.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When King Jeroboam heard the man of God condemning the altar in Bethel, he pointed to the man across the altar. “Arrest him,” he said. But the arm that he used to point to the man of God was paralyzed so that he couldn’t pull it back.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The altar was torn apart, and the ashes from the altar were poured on the ground. This was the miraculous sign the man of God performed at the Lord’s command.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king asked the man of God, “Please make an appeal to the Lord your God, and pray for me so that I can use my arm again.” So the man of God made an appeal to the Lord, and the king was able to use his arm again, as he had earlier.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king told the man of God, “Come home with me; have something to eat and drink, and I will give you a gift.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man of God told the king, “Even if you gave me half of your palace, I would never go with you to eat or drink there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Lord spoke to me, he commanded me not to eat or drink or go back on the same road I took.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the man of God left on another road and didn’t go back on the road he had taken to Bethel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: An old prophet was living in Bethel. His sons told him everything the man of God did in Bethel that day and the exact words he had spoken to the king. When they told their father,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he said to them, “Which road did he take?” (His sons had seen which road the man of God from Judah had taken.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The old prophet told his sons, “Saddle the donkey for me.” After they had saddled the donkey for him, he got on it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He went after the man of God and found him sitting under an oak tree. The old prophet asked him, “Are you the man of God who came from Judah?”
“Yes,” he answered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Come home with me, and eat a meal,” the old prophet replied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man of God said, “I’m not allowed to go back with you. I’m not allowed to eat or drink with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Lord spoke to me, he told me not to eat or drink there or go back on the road I took to get there.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The old prophet said, “I’m also a prophet, like you. An angel spoke the Lord’s word to me. He said, ‘Bring him home with you so that he may have something to eat and drink.’ ” (But the old prophet was lying.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man of God went back with him and ate and drank in his home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they were sitting at the table, the Lord spoke his word to the old prophet who had brought back the man of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord also called to the man of God. He said, “This is what the Lord says: You rebelled against the words from the Lord’s mouth and didn’t obey the command that the Lord your God gave you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You came back, ate, and drank at this place about which he told you, ‘Don’t eat or drink there.’ That is why your dead body will not be allowed to be placed in the tomb of your ancestors.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After the old prophet had something to eat and drink, he saddled the donkey for the prophet whom he had brought back.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man of God left. A lion found him as he traveled on the road and killed him. His dead body was thrown on the road. The donkey and the lion were standing by the body.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: People who passed by saw the body lying on the road and the lion standing by the body. They talked about it in the city where the old prophet was living.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the old prophet who had brought the man of God back from the road heard about it, he said, “It’s the man of God who rebelled against the words from the Lord’s mouth! The Lord gave him to the lion. It tore him to pieces and killed him as the Lord’s word had told him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the old prophet told his sons to saddle his donkey for him. So they did.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He found the body of the man thrown on the road. He also found the donkey and the lion standing beside it. The lion had not eaten the body, nor had it torn the donkey to pieces.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The old prophet picked up the body of the man of God, laid it on the donkey, and brought it back. He came to his own city to mourn for him and to bury him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He laid the body of the man of God in his own tomb and mourned over the man, saying, “Oh no, my brother, my brother!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After he had buried the man of God, he said to his sons, “When I die, bury me in the tomb where the man of God was buried. Lay my bones beside his bones.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The things that he announced by a command of the Lord against the altar in Bethel and all the illegal worship sites in the cities of Samaria will happen.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even after this, Jeroboam didn’t change his evil ways, but he once again made some men priests for the illegal worship sites. He took all who were willing and appointed them to be priests at the worship sites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Appointing illegal priests became the sin of Jeroboam’s family so that it had to be destroyed and wiped off the face of the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time Abijah, son of Jeroboam, got sick.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeroboam told his wife, “Go to Shiloh, but disguise yourself so that people will not recognize you as my wife. The prophet Ahijah, who told me I would be king of these people, is there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take ten loaves of bread, some raisins, and a jar of honey with you, and go to him. He will tell you what will happen to the boy.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Jeroboam’s wife did this. She left, went to Shiloh, and came to the home of Ahijah.
Ahijah couldn’t see. His eyesight had failed because he was old.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, the Lord had told Ahijah, “Jeroboam’s wife is coming to ask you about her son who is sick. When she comes, she will pretend to be someone else.” He also told Ahijah what to say to her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahijah heard her footsteps when she came into the room. He said, “Come in. You’re Jeroboam’s wife. Why are you pretending to be someone else? I’ve been told to give you some terrible news.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tell Jeroboam, ‘This is what the Lord God of Israel says: I picked you out of the people and made you a leader over my people Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I tore the kingdom away from David’s heirs and gave it to you. But you have not been like my servant David. He obeyed my commands and faithfully followed me by doing only what I considered right.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You have done more evil things than everyone before you. You made other gods, metal idols, for yourself. You made me furious and turned your back to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “ ‘That is why I will bring disaster on Jeroboam’s house. I will destroy every male  in his house, whether slave or freeman in Israel. I will burn down Jeroboam’s house. It will burn like manure until it is gone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If anyone from Jeroboam’s house dies in the city, dogs will eat him. If anyone dies in the country, birds will eat him.’ The Lord has said this!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Get up, and go home. The moment you set foot in the city the child will die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All Israel will mourn for him and bury him. He is the only one of Jeroboam’s family who will be properly buried. He was the only one in Jeroboam’s house in whom the Lord God of Israel found anything good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord will appoint a king over Israel. That king will destroy Jeroboam’s house. This will happen today. It will happen right now.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The Lord will strike Israel like cattails which shake in the water. He will uproot Israel from this good land which he gave their ancestors. He will scatter them beyond the Euphrates River because they dedicated poles to the goddess Asherah and made the Lord furious.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord will desert Israel because of Jeroboam’s sins, the sins which he led Israel to commit.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeroboam’s wife got up, left, and went to Tirzah. When she walked across the threshold of her home, the boy died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All Israel buried him and mourned for him as the Lord had said through his servant, the prophet Ahijah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everything else concerning Jeroboam, his wars, and his reign is written in the official records of the kings of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeroboam ruled for 22 years. Then he lay down in death with his ancestors. His son Nadab succeeded him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rehoboam, son of Solomon, ruled Judah. He was 41 years old when he began to rule. He ruled for 17 years in Jerusalem, the city that the Lord chose from all the tribes of Israel, the city where the Lord put his name. Rehoboam’s mother was an Ammonite woman named Naamah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Judah did what the Lord considered evil. Their sins made him more angry than anything their ancestors had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They built worship sites for themselves and put up large stones and Asherah poles to worship on every high hill and under every large tree.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were even male prostitutes in the temples of idols throughout the land. The people of Judah did all the disgusting practices done by the nations that the Lord had forced out of the Israelites’ way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the fifth year of Rehoboam’s reign, King Shishak of Egypt attacked Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He took the treasures from the Lord’s temple and the royal palace. He took them all. He took all the gold shields Solomon had made.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So King Rehoboam made bronze shields to replace them and put them by the entrance to the royal palace, where the captains of the guards were stationed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whenever the king went into the Lord’s temple, guards carried the shields and then returned them to the guardroom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isn’t everything else concerning Rehoboam—everything he did—written in the official records of the kings of Judah?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was war between Rehoboam and Jeroboam as long as they lived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rehoboam lay down in death with his ancestors and was buried with them in the City of David. (His mother was an Ammonite woman named Naamah.) His son Abijam succeeded him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the eighteenth year of the reign of Jeroboam (Nebat’s son), Abijam began to rule Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He ruled for three years in Jerusalem. His mother was named Maacah, daughter of Abishalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He followed the sinful example his father had set and wasn’t committed to the Lord his God as his ancestor David had been.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But for David’s sake the Lord his God made Abijam a lamp in Jerusalem. He appointed David’s descendant to rule after him and protected Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord did this because David did what the Lord considered right: David never failed to do anything the Lord commanded him to do his entire life (except in the matter concerning Uriah the Hittite).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was war between Abijam  and Rehoboam throughout their lives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isn’t everything else about Abijam—everything he did—written in the official records of the kings of Judah? There was war between Abijam and Jeroboam.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abijam lay down in death with his ancestors and was buried in the City of David. His son Asa succeeded him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In Jeroboam’s twentieth year as king of Israel, Asa began to rule as king of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He ruled 41 years in Jerusalem. His grandmother was named Maacah, daughter of Abishalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asa did what the Lord considered right, as his ancestor David had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He forced the male temple prostitutes out of the land and got rid of the idols his father had made.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also removed his grandmother Maacah from the position of queen mother because she made a statue of the repulsive goddess Asherah. Asa cut the statue down and burned it in the Kidron Valley.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Although the illegal worship sites were not torn down, Asa remained committed to the Lord his entire life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He brought into the Lord’s temple the silver, the gold, and the utensils he and his father had set apart as holy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was war between Asa and King Baasha of Israel as long as they lived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Baasha of Israel invaded Judah and fortified Ramah to keep anyone from going to or coming from King Asa of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Asa took all the silver and gold that was left in the treasuries of the Lord’s temple and the royal palace and turned them over to his officials. King Asa sent them to Damascus to Aram’s King Benhadad, son of Tabrimmon and grandson of Hezion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “There’s a treaty between you and me as there was between your father and my father. I’m sending you a present of silver and gold. Now break your treaty with King Baasha of Israel so that he will leave me alone.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Benhadad did what King Asa requested. He sent his generals and their armies to attack the cities of Israel. He conquered Ijon, Dan, Abel Beth Maacah, and the entire area around Chinneroth with the entire territory of Naphtali.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Baasha heard the news, he stopped fortifying Ramah and lived in Tirzah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King Asa drafted everyone in Judah and excused no one. He made them carry the stones and lumber from Ramah. Baasha had been using those to fortify the city. King Asa used the materials to fortify Geba in Benjamin and Mizpah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isn’t everything else about Asa—all his heroic acts, everything he did, and the cities he fortified—written in the official records of the kings of Judah? But when he was old, he had a foot disease.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asa lay down in death with his ancestors. He was buried with his ancestors in the city of his ancestor, David. His son Jehoshaphat succeeded him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nadab, son of Jeroboam, began to rule Israel in Asa’s second year as king of Judah. He ruled for two years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did what the Lord considered evil, living as his father did, leading Israel into the same sins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Baasha, son of Ahijah from the tribe of Issachar, plotted against Nadab. Baasha assassinated him in the Philistine city of Gibbethon while Nadab and the Israelite forces were attacking it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The assassination happened in Asa’s third year as king of Judah. Baasha succeeded Nadab as king of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as he was king, he killed everyone else in Jeroboam’s family. He did not spare a soul, as the Lord had spoken through his servant Ahijah from Shiloh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This was because of Jeroboam’s sins and the sins which he led Israel to commit. Those sins made the Lord God of Israel furious.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isn’t everything else about Nadab—everything he did—written in the official records of the kings of Israel?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was war between Asa and Baasha as long as they lived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In Asa’s third year as king of Judah, Baasha, son of Ahijah, began to rule Israel in Tirzah. He ruled for 24 years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did what the Lord considered evil. He lived like Jeroboam and led Israel into committing the same sins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord spoke his word to Jehu, Hanani’s son, against Baasha.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “I raised you from the dust and made you leader of my people Israel. But you have lived like Jeroboam. You have led my people to sin, and their sins make me furious.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I will destroy Baasha and his family. I will make his family like the family of Jeroboam (Nebat’s son).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Dogs will eat anyone from Baasha’s family who dies in the city. Birds will eat anyone from his family who dies in the country.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isn’t everything else about Baasha—what he did and his heroic acts—written in the official records of the kings of Israel?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Baasha lay down in death with his ancestors and was buried in Tirzah. His son Elah succeeded him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In addition, the Lord spoke his word to the prophet Jehu, Hanani’s son, against Baasha and his family because of all the things Baasha did which the Lord considered evil. Baasha’s actions, which made the Lord furious, were like the sin of Jeroboam’s family. The Lord was also furious because Baasha destroyed Jeroboam’s family.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elah, son of Baasha, began to rule Israel in Asa’s twenty-sixth year as Judah’s king. He ruled in Tirzah for two years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Zimri, the general who commanded half of Elah’s chariots, plotted against him. Elah was getting drunk in Tirzah at Arza’s house. (Arza was in charge of the palace in Tirzah.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zimri entered Arza’s house, attacked Elah, and killed him in Asa’s twenty-seventh year as king of Judah. Zimri succeeded Elah as king of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the beginning of Zimri’s reign, as soon as he was on his throne, he killed Baasha’s entire family. He didn’t spare any of Baasha’s male  relatives or friends.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Zimri destroyed Baasha’s entire family, as the Lord had spoken through the prophet Jehu.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This was for all the sins committed by Baasha and his son Elah. They sinned, led Israel to sin, and made the Lord God of Israel furious because of their worthless idols.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isn’t everything else about Elah—everything he did—written in the official records of the kings of Israel?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In Asa’s twenty-seventh year as Judah’s king, Zimri ruled for seven days in Tirzah while the army was camped near the Philistine city of Gibbethon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the army heard that Zimri had plotted against the king and killed him, the Israelite troops in the camp made Omri, the commander of the army, king of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Omri and the Israelite troops with him left Gibbethon and attacked Tirzah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Zimri saw that the city had been captured, he went into the stronghold in the royal palace and burned down the palace over his own head. He died
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because of the sins he had committed—the things the Lord considered evil. Zimri lived like Jeroboam and led Israel to sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isn’t everything else about Zimri and his plot written in the official records of the kings of Israel?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the army of Israel was divided into two factions. Half of the army followed Tibni, son of Ginath, and wanted to make him king. The other half followed Omri.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the half which followed Omri was stronger than the half which followed Tibni, Ginath’s son. Tibni died, and Omri became king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Omri began to rule Israel in Asa’s thirty-first year as king of Judah. He ruled for 12 years, 6 of them in Tirzah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Omri bought a hill from Shemer for 150 pounds of silver. He fortified the hill and built the city of Samaria on it. He named the city after its former owner, Shemer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Omri did what the Lord considered evil. He did more evil things than all the kings before him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He lived exactly like Jeroboam (Nebat’s son). He sinned and led Israel to sin with worthless idols, and the Israelites made the Lord God of Israel furious.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isn’t everything else about Omri—what he did and his heroic acts—written in the official records of the kings of Israel?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Omri lay down in death with his ancestors and was buried in Samaria. His son Ahab succeeded him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahab, son of Omri, began to rule Israel in Asa’s thirty-eighth year as king of Judah. He ruled for 22 years in Samaria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahab, son of Omri, did what the Lord considered evil. He was worse than all the kings who were before him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It wasn’t enough that he committed the same sins as Jeroboam (Nebat’s son). He also married Jezebel, daughter of King Ethbaal of Sidon. Ahab then served and worshiped Baal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He built the temple of Baal in Samaria and set up an altar there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahab made poles dedicated to the goddess Asherah. He did more to make the Lord God of Israel furious than all the kings of Israel who came before him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In Ahab’s time Hiel from Bethel rebuilt Jericho.
Laying the foundation
cost him his firstborn son, Abiram.
Setting up the city doors
cost him his youngest son, Segub.
The Lord had spoken this through Joshua, son of Nun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elijah, who was from Tishbe but had settled in Gilead, said to Ahab, “I solemnly swear, as the Lord God of Israel whom I serve lives, there will be no dew or rain during the next few years unless I say so.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord spoke his word to Elijah:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Leave here, turn east, and hide beside the Cherith River, which is east of the Jordan River.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You can drink from the stream, and I’ve commanded ravens to feed you there.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elijah left and did what the Lord’s word had told him. He went to live by the Cherith River, which is east of the Jordan River.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ravens brought him bread and meat in the morning and in the evening. And he drank from the stream.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But after some time the stream dried up because no rain had fallen in the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord spoke his word to Elijah:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Get up, go to Zarephath (which belongs to Sidon), and stay there. I’ve commanded a widow there to feed you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He got up and went to Zarephath. As he came to the town’s entrance, a widow was gathering wood. He called to her, “Please bring me a drink of water.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As she was going to get it, he called to her again, “Please bring me a piece of bread too.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She said, “I solemnly swear, as the Lord your God lives, I didn’t bake any bread. I have one handful of flour in a jar and a little oil in a jug. I’m gathering wood. I’m going to prepare something for myself and my son so that we can eat it and then die.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Elijah told her, “Don’t be afraid. Go home, and do as you’ve said. But first make a small loaf and bring it to me. Then prepare something for yourself and your son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord God of Israel says: Until the Lord sends rain on the land, the jar of flour will never be empty and the jug will always contain oil.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She did what Elijah had told her. So she, Elijah, and her family had food for a long time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The jar of flour never became empty, and the jug always contained olive oil, as the Lord had promised through Elijah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Afterwards, the son of the woman who owned the house got sick. He got so sick that finally no life was left in him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The woman asked Elijah, “What do you and I have in common, man of God? Did you come here to remind me of my sin and kill my son?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to her, “Give me your son.” Elijah took him from her arms, carried him to the upstairs room where he was staying, and laid him on his own bed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he called to the Lord, “Lord my God, have you brought misery on the widow I’m staying with by killing her son?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Elijah stretched himself over the boy three times and called to the Lord, “Lord my God, please make this child’s life return to him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord heard Elijah’s request, and the child’s life returned to him. He was alive again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elijah took the child, brought him down from the upstairs room of the house, and gave him to his mother. He said, “Look! Your son is alive.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The woman said to Elijah, “Now I’m convinced that you are a man of God and that the Lord’s word from your mouth is true.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A while later in the third year of the drought, the Lord spoke his word to Elijah: “Present yourself to Ahab. I will allow rain to fall on the ground.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So Elijah went to present himself to Ahab.
The famine was particularly severe in Samaria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahab sent for Obadiah, who was in charge of the palace. Obadiah was a devout worshiper of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (When Jezebel was killing the Lord’s prophets, Obadiah had hidden 100 prophets in caves. He put 50 prophets in each cave and kept them alive by providing bread and water for them.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahab told Obadiah, “Let’s go throughout the countryside to every spring and stream. If we can find grass, then we can keep the horses and mules alive and not lose any animals.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they split up in order to cover the entire countryside. Ahab went one way by himself, and Obadiah went the other way by himself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Obadiah was on the road when he met Elijah. Obadiah recognized him and immediately bowed down to the ground. “Is it you, my master Elijah?” he asked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Yes,” Elijah answered him. “Tell your master that Elijah is here.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Obadiah asked, “What have I done wrong to make you hand me over to Ahab to be killed?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I solemnly swear, as the Lord your God lives, my master has searched for you in every region and kingdom. When people would say, ‘He isn’t here,’ my master made that kingdom or region take an oath that they hadn’t found you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now you say, ‘Tell your master that Elijah is here.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what will happen: When I leave you, the Lord’s Spirit will take you away to some unknown place. I’ll tell Ahab, but he won’t be able to find you. Then he will kill me.
“I have been faithful to the Lord since I was a child.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Haven’t you heard what I did when Jezebel killed the Lord’s prophets? Haven’t you heard how I hid 100 of the Lord’s prophets in caves? I hid 50 prophets in each cave and provided bread and water for them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now you say that I should tell my master that Elijah is here. He will kill me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elijah said, “I solemnly swear, as the Lord of Armies whom I serve lives, I will present myself to Ahab.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So Obadiah went to tell Ahab.
Ahab went to meet Elijah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he saw Elijah, Ahab said, “Is that you, you troublemaker of Israel?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elijah answered, “I haven’t troubled Israel. You and your father’s family have done it by disobeying the Lord’s commands and following the various Baal gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Order all Israel to gather around me on Mount Carmel. And bring the 450 prophets of Baal and 400 prophets of Asherah who eat at Jezebel’s table.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahab sent word to all the Israelites and brought the prophets together on Mount Carmel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elijah stood up in front of all the people and asked them, “How long will you try to have it both ways? If the Lord is God, follow him; if Baal is God, follow him.” The people didn’t say a word.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Elijah told the people, “I’m the only surviving prophet of the Lord, but there are 450 prophets of Baal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Give us two bulls. Let the prophets of Baal choose one for themselves, cut it into pieces, lay it on the wood, but not set it on fire. I’ll do the same with the other bull.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“You call on the name of your gods, but I will call on the name of the Lord. The god who answers by fire is the real God.”
All the people answered, “That’s fine.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elijah told the prophets of Baal, “Choose one bull for yourselves. Prepare yours first, because there are more of you. Call on the name of your god, but don’t set the wood on fire.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They took the bull he gave them, prepared it, and called on the name of Baal from morning until noon. They said, “Baal, answer us!” But there wasn’t a sound or an answer. So they danced around the altar they had made.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At noon Elijah started to make fun of them. “Shout louder, since he is a god. Maybe he’s thinking, relieving himself, or traveling! Maybe he’s sleeping, and you have to wake him!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they shouted louder. They also cut themselves with swords and spears until their blood flowed. (This is what their ritual called for.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the afternoon they continued to rant and rave until the time for the evening sacrifice. But there was no sound, no answer, no attention given to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Elijah said to all the people, “Come over here.” So all the people came to him. He rebuilt the Lord’s altar that had been torn down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elijah took 12 stones, one for each of the tribes named after Jacob’s sons. (The Lord had spoken his word to Jacob: “Your name will be Israel.”)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elijah built an altar in the Lord’s name with those stones. He also made a trench that could hold 12 quarts of grain around the altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He arranged the wood, cut up the bull, and put it on the wood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “Fill four jars with water. Pour the water on the offering and on the wood.” Then he said, “Do it again,” and they did it again. Then he said, “Do it a third time,” and they did it a third time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The water flowed around the altar, and even the trench was filled with water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When it was time to offer the sacrifice, the prophet Elijah stepped forward. He said, “Lord God of Abraham, Isaac, and Israel, make known today that you are God in Israel and that I’m your servant and have done all these things by your instructions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Answer me, Lord! Answer me! Then these people will know that you, Lord, are God and that you are winning back their hearts.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So a fire from the Lord fell down and consumed the burnt offering, wood, stones, and dirt. The fire even dried up the water that was in the trench.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people saw it and immediately bowed down to the ground. “The Lord is God!” they said. “The Lord is God!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elijah told them, “Seize the prophets of Baal. Don’t let any of them escape.” The people seized them, and Elijah took them to the Kishon River and slaughtered them there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Elijah told Ahab, “Get up, eat, and drink. It sounds like a heavy rain is coming.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Ahab got up to eat and drink.
Elijah went to the top of Carmel and bowed down on the ground to pray.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He said to his servant, “Please go back to Mount Carmel, and look toward the sea.”
He went up, looked, came back, and said, “There’s nothing.”
Seven times Elijah told him, “Go back.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
After the seventh time the servant said, “A little cloud like a man’s hand is coming from the sea.”
Elijah said, “Go and tell Ahab, ‘Prepare your chariot, and leave before the rain delays you.’ ”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gradually, the sky grew darker with clouds and wind, and there was a heavy rain. Ahab got into his chariot to go back to Jezreel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord’s power was on Elijah. He hiked up his robe and ran ahead of Ahab until they came to Jezreel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahab told Jezebel everything Elijah had done, including how he had executed all the prophets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jezebel sent a messenger to Elijah. She said, “May the gods strike me dead if by this time tomorrow I don’t take your life the way you took the lives of Baal’s prophets.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Frightened, Elijah fled to save his life. He came to Beersheba in Judah and left his servant there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he traveled through the wilderness for a day. He sat down under a broom plant and wanted to die. “I’ve had enough now, Lord,” he said. “Take my life! I’m no better than my ancestors.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then he lay down and slept under the broom plant.
An angel touched him and said, “Get up and eat.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he looked, he saw near his head some bread baked on hot stones and a jar of water. So he ate, drank, and went to sleep again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The angel of the Lord came back and woke him up again. The angel said, “Get up and eat, or your journey will be too much for you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He got up, ate, and drank. Strengthened by that food, he traveled for 40 days and nights until he came to Horeb, the mountain of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There he went into a cave and spent the night.
Then the Lord spoke his word to Elijah. He asked, “What are you doing here, Elijah?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He answered, “Lord God of Armies, I have eagerly served you. The Israelites have abandoned your promises, torn down your altars, and executed your prophets. I’m the only one left, and they’re trying to take my life.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
God said, “Go out and stand in front of the Lord on the mountain.”
As the Lord was passing by, a fierce wind tore mountains and shattered rocks ahead of the Lord. But the Lord was not in the wind. After the wind came an earthquake. But the Lord wasn’t in the earthquake.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After the earthquake there was a fire. But the Lord wasn’t in the fire. And after the fire there was a quiet, whispering voice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When Elijah heard it, he wrapped his face in his coat, went out, and stood at the entrance of the cave.
Then the voice said to him, “What are you doing here, Elijah?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He answered, “Lord God of Armies, I have eagerly served you. The Israelites have abandoned your promises, torn down your altars, and executed your prophets. I’m the only one left, and they’re trying to take my life.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord told him, “Go back to the wilderness near Damascus, the same way you came. When you get there, anoint Hazael as king of Aram.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Anoint Jehu, son of Nimshi, as king of Israel. And anoint Elisha, son of Shaphat, from Abel Meholah as prophet to take your place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If anyone escapes from Hazael’s sword, Jehu will kill him. And if anyone escapes from Jehu’s sword, Elisha will kill him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I still have 7,000 people in Israel whose knees have not knelt to worship Baal and whose mouths have not kissed him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elijah found Elisha, son of Shaphat. Elisha was plowing behind 12 pairs of oxen. He was using the twelfth pair. Elijah took off his coat and put it on Elisha.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So Elisha left the oxen, ran after Elijah, and said, “Please let me kiss my father and mother goodbye. Then I will follow you.”
“Go back,” Elijah answered him. “I’m not stopping you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elisha left him, took two oxen, and butchered them. He boiled the meat, using the oxen’s yoke  for firewood. He gave the meat to the people to eat. Then he left to follow and assist Elijah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Benhadad of Aram gathered together his whole army. With him were 32 kings along with their horses and chariots. He went to blockade Samaria and fight against it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He sent messengers into the city to King Ahab of Israel. They told Ahab, “This is what Benhadad says:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your silver and gold are mine. Your beloved wives and children are mine.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Israel answered, “As you say, Your Majesty. I and everything I have are yours.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Benhadad sent messengers back to Ahab. They said, “Benhadad has sent this message to you: ‘Your silver, gold, wives, and children are mine. Give them to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At this time tomorrow I’m going to send my servants to search your palace and your servants’ houses. They will take anything that you consider valuable.’ ”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king of Israel called for all the leaders of the country. He said, “You can see how this man is looking for trouble. When he sent for my wives, children, silver, and gold, I didn’t refuse him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the leaders and all the people told him, “Don’t listen to him. Don’t agree to his demands.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahab told Benhadad’s messengers, “Tell His Majesty, ‘I did everything your messengers told me the first time, but I can’t do this.’ ” The messengers left to take back his answer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Benhadad sent Ahab the following message: “May the gods strike me dead if there will be enough dust left from Samaria to give a handful to each soldier who follows me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Israel answered, “The saying goes, ‘Don’t brag about a victory before you have even dressed for battle.’ ”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Benhadad heard this as he and his allies were drinking in their tents. He told his officers to get ready. So they got ready to attack the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then a prophet came to King Ahab of Israel and said, “This is what the Lord says: Have you seen this large army? I will hand it over to you today. Then you will know that I am the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Ahab asked, “How will this be done?”
The prophet answered, “This is what the Lord says: by using the young officers of the district governors.”
“Who will start the battle?” Ahab asked.
“You will,” the prophet answered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahab counted the young officers of the district governors. There were 232. After counting them, he counted all the Israelite soldiers. There were 7,000.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They attacked at noon, when Benhadad was in his tent getting drunk with the 32 kings who were his allies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The young officers of the district governors went out first.
Benhadad had sent men to watch the city. They informed him that some men had come out of Samaria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “Take them alive, whether they have come out to make peace or to fight.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The young officers of the district governors led an attack, and the troops followed them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each officer killed his opponent. The Arameans fled, and Israel pursued them. King Benhadad of Aram escaped on a horse with the cavalry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Israel went out and destroyed the horses and chariots and decisively defeated the Arameans.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the prophet came to the king of Israel and said, “Reinforce your army. Consider what you have to do. When spring comes, the king of Aram will attack again.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, the officers of King Benhadad of Aram told him, “Their god is a god of the hills. That is why they were stronger than we were. However, if we fight them on the plain, we will be stronger than they are.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what we must do: Remove all of the kings from their positions, and substitute governors for them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Recruit an army with as many horses and chariots as the one which was defeated. Then, if we fight them on the plain, we will be stronger than they are.” He took their advice and followed it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Spring came, and Benhadad organized the Aramean army and went to Aphek to fight Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Israelite troops had been organized and given provisions, they went to meet the enemy. The Israelites, while camped opposite the Arameans who filled the country, seemed like two newborn goats.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man of God came again. He said to the king of Israel, “This is what the Lord says: Because the Arameans said that the Lord is a god of the hills but not a god of the valleys, I will hand over their entire army to you. Then you will know that I am the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They camped facing one another for seven days, and on the seventh day the battle started. The Israelites killed 100,000 Aramean foot soldiers in one day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The survivors fled to Aphek, the city where the wall fell on 27,000 of them. Benhadad had also fled. He came to the city and hid in an inner room.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His officers told him, “We have heard that the kings of Israel are merciful. Allow us to dress in sackcloth, put ropes around our necks, and go to the king of Israel. Maybe he’ll let you live.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So they dressed in sackcloth and put ropes around their necks. They went to the king of Israel and said, “Your servant Benhadad says, ‘Please let me live.’ ”
Ahab asked, “He’s still alive? He’s my brother.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The men, watching for a good sign, were quick to take him at his word. “Benhadad is your brother,” they said.
Ahab said, “Bring him here.” When Benhadad arrived, Ahab had him come up on the chariot with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Benhadad told him, “I will give back the towns my father took from your father. You may set up trading centers in Damascus as my father did in Samaria.”
Ahab said, “If you will put this into a treaty, I will let you go.” So Ahab made a treaty with Benhadad and let him go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A disciple of the prophets spoke to a friend as the Lord’s word had told him. The disciple said, “Punch me,” but the man refused to punch him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The disciple said, “Since you didn’t obey the Lord, a lion will kill you when you leave me.” When the friend left, a lion found him and killed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the disciple found another man. He said, “Punch me.” The man punched him hard and wounded him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the prophet, disguised with a bandage over his eyes, waited for the king by the road.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the king passed by, the disciple called to him. “I went to fight in the battle. A man turned around and brought a prisoner to me. He said, ‘Guard this prisoner. If he gets away, you will pay for his life with your own life or be fined 75 pounds of silver.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But while I was busy doing other things, he got away.”
The king of Israel told him, “That’s your own penalty. You have determined it yourself.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he quickly took the bandage off his eyes. The king of Israel recognized him as one of the prophets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The prophet told him, “This is what the Lord says: You let the man go. He was claimed by God and should have been killed. For that reason your life will be taken in place of his life and your people in place of his people.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Resentful and upset, the king of Israel went home to Samaria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what happened next. Naboth from Jezreel had a vineyard in Jezreel next to the palace of King Ahab of Samaria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahab told Naboth, “Give me your vineyard. It will become my vegetable garden because it is near my house. I will give you a better vineyard for it. Or if you prefer, I will pay you a fair price for it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Naboth told Ahab, “The Lord has forbidden me to give you what I inherited from my ancestors.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Resentful and upset, Ahab went home because of what Naboth from Jezreel had told him. (Naboth had said, “I will not give you what I inherited from my ancestors.”) So Ahab lay on the couch, turned his face from everyone, and refused to eat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His wife Jezebel came to him and asked, “Why are you so resentful of everything? Why don’t you eat?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He told her, “I talked to Naboth from Jezreel. I said to him, ‘Sell me your vineyard. Or, if you like, I’ll give you another vineyard for it.’ But he said, ‘I won’t give you my vineyard.’ ”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His wife Jezebel said to him, “Aren’t you king of Israel? Get up, eat, and cheer up. I’ll give you the vineyard belonging to Naboth from Jezreel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jezebel wrote letters, signed them with Ahab’s name, and sealed them with his seal. She sent them to the respected leaders and nobles living in Naboth’s city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In these letters she wrote: “Announce a fast. Seat Naboth as leader of the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Have two good-for-nothing men sit opposite him and accuse him of cursing God and the king. Then stone him to death outside the city.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men in Naboth’s city—the respected leaders and nobles who lived there—did what Jezebel asked them to do. They did just as she had written in the letters she sent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They announced a fast and had Naboth seated as the leader of the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The two good-for-nothing men came in and sat opposite him. In front of the people, these men accused Naboth of cursing God and the king. So the people stoned him to death outside the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the leaders sent this message to Jezebel: “Naboth has been stoned to death.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jezebel received the message and said to Ahab, “Get up! Confiscate the vineyard which Naboth from Jezreel refused to sell you. He’s dead now.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he heard about Naboth’s death, Ahab went to confiscate the vineyard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord spoke his word to Elijah from Tishbe:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go, meet King Ahab of Israel, who lives in Samaria. He went to confiscate Naboth’s vineyard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tell him, ‘This is what the Lord asks: Have you murdered someone just to confiscate a vineyard?’ Then tell him, ‘This is what the Lord says: At the place where the dogs licked up Naboth’s blood, the dogs will lick up your blood.’ ”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Ahab asked Elijah, “So you’ve found me, my enemy?”
Elijah answered, “I found you. Because you sold yourself to do what the Lord considers evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I am going to bring evil on you. I will destroy your descendants. I will destroy every male  in Ahab’s house, whether slave or freeman in Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will make your family like the family of Jeroboam (Nebat’s son) and like the house of Baasha, son of Ahijah, because you made me furious. You led Israel to sin.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord also spoke through Elijah about Jezebel: “The dogs will eat Jezebel inside the walls of Jezreel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If anyone from Ahab’s house dies in the city, dogs will eat him. If anyone dies in the country, birds will eat him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was no one else like Ahab. At the urging of his wife, he sold himself to do what the Lord considered evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did many disgusting things as a result of worshiping idols as the Amorites had done. (The Lord confiscated their land for Israel.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Ahab heard these things, he tore his clothes in distress and dressed in sackcloth. He fasted, lay in sackcloth, and walked around depressed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord spoke his word to Elijah from Tishbe:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do you see how Ahab is humbling himself in my presence? Because he’s humbling himself in my presence, I will not let any evil happen to his family while he is alive. I will bring evil on it during his son’s lifetime.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For three years there was no war between Aram and Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the third year King Jehoshaphat of Judah went to visit the king of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Israel asked his staff, “Do you know that Ramoth in Gilead belongs to us, and we are doing nothing to take it back from the king of Aram?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then he asked Jehoshaphat, “Will you go with me to fight at Ramoth in Gilead?”
Jehoshaphat told the king of Israel, “I will do what you do. My troops will do what your troops do. My horses will do what your horses do.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jehoshaphat said to the king of Israel, “But first, find out what the Lord’s word is in this matter.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So the king of Israel called 400 prophets together. He asked them, “Should I go to war against Ramoth in Gilead or not?”
“Go,” they said. “The Lord  will hand over Ramoth to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jehoshaphat asked, “Isn’t there a prophet of the Lord whom we could ask?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king of Israel told Jehoshaphat, “We can ask the Lord through Micaiah, son of Imlah, but I hate him. He doesn’t prophesy anything good about me, only evil.”
Jehoshaphat answered, “The king must not say that.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Israel called for an officer and said, “Quick! Get Micaiah, son of Imlah!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Israel and King Jehoshaphat of Judah were dressed in royal robes and seated on thrones. They were on the threshing floor  at the entrance to the gate of Samaria. All the prophets were prophesying in front of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zedekiah, son of Chenaanah, made iron horns and said, “This is what the Lord says: With these horns you will push the Arameans to their destruction.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the other prophets made the same prophecy. They said, “Attack Ramoth in Gilead, and you will win. The Lord will hand it over to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The messenger who went to call Micaiah told him, “The prophets have all told the king the same good message. Make your message agree with their message. Say something good.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Micaiah answered, “I solemnly swear, as the Lord lives, I will tell him whatever the Lord tells me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When he came to the king, the king asked him, “Micaiah, should we go to war against Ramoth in Gilead or not?”
Micaiah said to him, “Attack and you will win. The Lord will hand it over to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king asked him, “How many times must I make you take an oath in the Lord’s name to tell me nothing but the truth?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Micaiah said, “I saw Israel’s troops scattered in the hills like sheep without a shepherd. The Lord said, ‘These sheep have no master. Let each one go home in peace.’ ”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, “Didn’t I tell you he wouldn’t prophesy anything good about me, only evil?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Micaiah added, “Then hear the Lord’s word. I saw the Lord sitting on his throne, and the entire army of heaven was standing near him on his right and his left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord asked, ‘Who will deceive Ahab so that he will attack and be killed at Ramoth in Gilead?’ Some answered one way, while others said something else.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Then the Spirit stepped forward, stood in front of the Lord, and said, ‘I will deceive him.’
“ ‘How?’ the Lord asked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“The Spirit answered, ‘I will go out and be a spirit that tells lies through the mouths of all of Ahab’s prophets.’
“The Lord said, ‘You will succeed in deceiving him. Go and do it.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “So, the Lord has put into the mouths of all these prophets of yours a spirit that makes them tell lies. The Lord has spoken evil about you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Zedekiah, son of Chenaanah, went to Micaiah and struck him on the cheek. “How did the Lord’s Spirit leave me to talk to you?” he asked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Micaiah answered, “You will find out on the day you go into an inner room to hide.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Israel then said, “Send Micaiah back to Amon, the governor of the city, and to Joash, the prince.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Say, ‘This is what the king says: Put this man in prison, and feed him nothing but bread and water until I come home safely.’ ”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Micaiah said, “If you really do come back safely, then the Lord wasn’t speaking through me. Pay attention to this, everyone!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king of Israel and King Jehoshaphat of Judah went to Ramoth in Gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Israel told Jehoshaphat, “I will disguise myself and go into battle, but you should wear your royal robes.” So the king of Israel disguised himself and went into battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Aram had given orders to the 32 chariot commanders. He said, “Don’t fight anyone except the king of Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the chariot commanders saw Jehoshaphat, they said, “He must be the king of Israel.” So they turned to fight him. But when Jehoshaphat cried out,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the chariot commanders realized that he wasn’t the king of Israel. They turned away from him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One man aimed his bow at random and hit the king of Israel between his scale armor and his breastplate. Ahab told his chariot driver, “Turn around, and get me away from these troops. I’m badly wounded.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the battle got worse that day, and the king was kept propped up in his chariot facing the Arameans. He died that evening. The blood from the wound had flowed into the chariot.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At sundown a cry went through the army, “Every man to his own city! Every man to his own property!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the king was dead, he was brought to Samaria to be buried.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His chariot was washed at the pool of Samaria, where the prostitutes bathed. The dogs licked up his blood, as the Lord had predicted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isn’t everything else about Ahab—everything he did, the ivory palace he built, and all the cities he fortified—written in the official records of the kings of Israel?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahab lay down in death with his ancestors. His son Ahaziah succeeded him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat, son of Asa, became king of Judah in Ahab’s fourth year as king of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat was 35 years old when he began to rule, and he ruled for 25 years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Azubah, daughter of Shilhi.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat carefully followed the example his father Asa had set and did what the Lord considered right.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the illegal worship sites were not torn down. The people continued to sacrifice and burn incense at these worship sites. Jehoshaphat made peace with the king of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isn’t everything else about Jehoshaphat—the heroic acts he did and the wars he fought—written in the official records of the kings of Judah?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He rid the land of the male temple prostitutes who were left there from the time of his father Asa.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was no king in Edom; instead, a deputy ruled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat made Tarshish-style ships to go to Ophir for gold. But they didn’t go because the ships were wrecked at Ezion Geber.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Ahaziah, son of Ahab, said to Jehoshaphat, “Let my servants go with your servants in the ships.” But Jehoshaphat refused.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat lay down in death with his ancestors and was buried with them in the city of his ancestor David. His son Jehoram succeeded him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahaziah, son of Ahab, became king of Israel in Samaria during Jehoshaphat’s seventeenth year as king of Judah. Ahaziah ruled Israel for two years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did what the Lord considered evil. He followed the example of his father and mother and of Jeroboam (Nebat’s son) who led Israel to sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahaziah served Baal, worshiped him, and made the Lord God of Israel furious, as his father had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator
